9/ I've chosen to weight them equally for the above example; it's useful to play around with that parameter and see how it affects the results.

8/ The reason for having these two measures is that we might not want a word to appear high on the list just because it gets used a lot everywhere; we can adjust how much each measure contributes to the ordering of words within topic areas.

7/ The analysis provides two different frequency measures for word occurences, one being the probability of a word appearing in a given topic area, and another (called "lift") that divides that probability by that word's overall frequency in the document.

6/ We see words like "causes" and "huel" showing up, but not words from another of my topic areas, "systems thinking." And realizing this, I might decide to try mixing these areas more when I talk about them if, e.g., I think that systems thinking might benefit EA causes.

5/ The analysis shown below is based off 3,000 of my tweets; they have been broken up into 10 topic areas. I've selected the one that most closely cooresponds to "things having to do with EA." https://t.co/rmgIXE3YBe

4/ It could also reveal patterns in the ways I'm using words to discuss those topics. For example, maybe I use language that's too informal to talk about things on which I'd like to confer a bit more gravitas.

3/ For example, suppose I would like to maintain a certain balance between areas that I tweet about. LDA might reveal that I hardly ever talk about something I thought I tweeted about often, and as a result I might decide to tweet about that topic more often.

2/ It can thus give a picture of what sorts of things are being written about as well as which words tend to be used together to talk about each thing; this knowledge can be useful for decision  making.

1/ Topic analysis or Latent Dirichlet Allocation breaks a collection of documents (such as tweets) up into topic areas and calculates probabilities for words to appear both overall and within specific areas.

6/ For that we can ask SQL to output a new column called "Sales Category", which will say "Low Seller" if less than 2 (of whatever units are being used) were sold "Medium Seller" if between 2 and 4 were sold, and "High Seller" if more than 4 were sold.

5/ If we only wanted to see, e.g., the Game, Genre, and "North America" columns, we would have typed "select Game, Genre, "North America" from gameSales", etc. Now suppose we want to see which games sold best in North America.

4/ The "select *" part tells SQL to extract data from all of the columns, but the "limit 5" part tells sql to show only the first 5 rows. We can see that there's data on the game title, year, genre, and publisher as well as how much was sold in different parts of the world.
3/ Then to get a first look at the data we can do this: https://t.co/Y7Z7OuDJha

2/ The ".mode csv" command tells SQL that we want to read a csv file; ".headers on" says that, when the table info is displayed, we want to see the column labels; the last command imports the file as a table called gameSales
1/ Okay so we've got a csv file about PS4 game sales; to look at it in sqlite we can do this: https://t.co/16IFauzVpc

5/ All I need to do is try to approximate my ideal self. Okay now everyone can start throwing coconut cream pies at me

4/ The utilitarian perspective has been the most useful of the three for me; one explanation for that is that it's more correct than the others (maybe my ideal self would just do that all time), but I don't feel like I need to take a position on it?

3/ I know that I can't be in this ideal state, but I can aspire toward it by trying to see a situation from as many perspectives as possible. So (among other things) I put on virtue, deontological, and utilitarian "hats" to see what each says about a situation

2/ My metaethics is thus a combo of emotivism and ideal observer theory: It seems to me that I want to do what I would want to do if I were in a certain ideal position, i.e., understanding all the relevant facts, including how it would feel to be others affected by my actions

1/ I'm gonna say what I think about ethics for a bit. I'm not highly confident about any of it; it's just what so far makes the most sense to me. First, I don't see how objective values could exist in the world: I'm a physicalist; it seems like, e.g., everything is quantum fields

as far as i can tell, the best balance between these extremes is to get good at detaching from beliefs as well as at paradigm jumping

there's anchoring, i.e., starting with a bad prior and/or not adjusting it enough in light of new evidence...

and then there's refusing to learn something that could be valuable due to fear of anchoring
a way to maximize the advantages of both kinds of view is to have an outsider come in and learn before evaluating

inspired by a certain person coming in and apparently firing all the insiders that would be most knowledgeable

there is an inverse relationship between complexity of a model and understanding it can convey

for example, a decision support ML algorithm based on cover letter/resume wording of past successful applicants can encode pernicious biases from past hiring, while just scoring based on a few well-chosen metrics might help avoid the issue
i‚Äôm saying this as someone who loves ML btw

learning institutions should have degree programs in integrative science, in which biology/chemistry/physics are taught together, not like Neapolitan ice cream flavors, but by showcasing how they are inextricably tangled up in the real-world‚Äôs pressing problems

Some extra details: The facilitator would be adding his/her thoughts to yours and recording the results of each step digitally using words and graphs.

5/ My question to you, dear reader, is this: Would you find it useful to role play these groups' positions yourself and be led through the process described above for some issue of importance to you, i.e., to simulate a SAST workshop, but with just you and a facilitator.

4/ After each group has presented and has its position criticized by the other groups, a synthesis is attempted that factors in the strong points of each group's original position; if a synthesis cannot be reached, at least the key uncertainties have been identified.

3/ Then each group is asked what assumptions they are making about various stakeholders in order for their position to be correct. These assumptions are then rated on certainty and importance: It's the assumptions of high uncertainty and high importance that are crucial.

2/ Each group defends a position on whatever the issue of relevance happens to be, such that the groups cover a good range of perspectives; for each group, if possible, there's another group defending an opposing view.

1/ So, there's this systems approach called SAST (Strategic Assumption Surfacing and Testing), in which you would typically do the following with a collection of people after separating them into groups:

5/ I suspect that intuition is a sensitive test for dangerous situations but that it is highly unspecific, i.e., that it gives lots of false alarms. Otoh, it can make sense to act as if those alarms were always accurate, for safety reasons (see also previous post).
4/ But the smoke detector isn't perfectly specific in this regard: Smoke from cooking or burning candles or incense could also make the alarm go off.
3/ If we think of the detector as a test, not just for smoke, but for the presence of an uncontrolled fire, then its sensitivity still seems high: A fire will very likely make the alarm go off.
2/ Usually a smoke detector is a highly sensitive test: If there's smoke then the alarm will almost definitely go off.
1/ I want to explain test sensitivity and specificity using the analogy of a smoke detector, and then use those conceptst o say something about intuition.

Actions don't always correspond directly to beliefs. 

I can strongly suspect that a gun is not loaded but, for safety reasons, choose to act as if it were loaded. 

Fairly often I see confusion on this point, and especially relating to trust in others...

@imperialauditor To be wrong in thinking you have a proof of P would be to show Prov(P) while P is in fact false. But that's impossible by assumption. So P is true. I think that's the best I can do without going and studying Godel's theorem üòÖ
@imperialauditor More briefly: If it's impossible to be wrong in thinking that you have a proof of P, then P must be true.
@imperialauditor I'm not feeling 100% clear about that explanation, but that's where I'm at so far.

@imperialauditor If Prov(P) implies (P) has been proven in some axiom system (the syntactic view), then any model that makes Prov(P) be true also makes P be true (that's the semantic view). So we can't make a model that mistakenly says Prov(P) when P is false. That must mean that P is true.

4/ But it's also important to remember that sometimes it's better to simply factor in uncertainty than to try to reduce it. After all, it takes resources (including time) to reduce uncertainties, and the gain in certainty that we can hope to achieve is not always worth it!

3/ Uncertainties about links to other decisions can be reduced by thinking deeply about those interrelationships and by engaging with those responsible in the other decision areas. Sometimes modeling is called for here as well.

2/ Uncertainties about our working environment are reduced by activities such as talking to experts, looking up information, or performing studies. Those about values can be reduced by considering carefully our own values and those of other people who our decisions may effect.

1/ It's often useful to divide uncertainties into three types: uncertainties about our working environment, uncertainties about which values to align with, and uncertainties about how the decions we're currently making relate to other ones that may or may not be up to us.

That is, we can pursue our goals in a way that allows maximum flexibility in an unknown future.

We often can't make plans far into the future, because the future far ahead is unpredictable. But we can consider several possible paths of action and evaluate their endpoints in a few possible futures; we can then choose to do things now that leave our future options open.

3/ Being multimethod is to do everything in the service of one perspective, being multimethodological is to switch between fundamentally different ways of viewing a problem situation.

2/ One can co-opt methods from many different frameworks, that is, one can be multimethod, without being multimethodological. It‚Äôs an important distinction because the latter is much more powerful than the former.

1/ It seems useful to distinguish between methodology and method: Methodology is a set of principles or guidelines for making or choosing methods based on some underlying theory; it is a bridge between theory and methods.

9/ By looking at systems as if they were organisms and asking whether modules 1-5 are present, how they are instantiated in each particular instance, and whether they are wired together correctly, we can very often find ways of increasing their viability.
8/ "System" here can be taken very broadly, like "the system of me, my social media accounts, and my blog" or "the system of me and my girlfriend", etc.
7/ The amazing thing about that model is that it provides a blueprint for how any system might best be designed to be able to thrive in a changing and largely unpredictable environment.

6/ If we continued this way and thought very hard about how modules 1-5 above would need to be wired to each other, we very well might end up with Stafford Beer's Viable System Model.

(Image by Mark Lambertz - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0) https://t.co/tIkmTHeOQz

5/ For the organisms to be purposeful, it would need a kind of executive control center that factors in what's going on in the other systems to some extent and gives meaning to the organism's experience.

4/ There would need to be a way for the organism to learn what's going on in its environment and consider more global changes it might make to its behavior in order to perform better, a kind of R&D center.
3/ The organism would need some way of sensing (not necessarily consciously) whether those interfaces were working properly and making the necessary changes if not.
2/ These interfaces would need to be coordinated with one another.
1/ There would need to be a set of interfaces through which the organism could sense and interact with its environment on a basic level.
0/ Think for a moment about what kinds of modules you would need, from a neurological perspective, in order to create a living, purposeful, organism that could survive in a turbulent environment.

5/ One of the ways to handle having too many decisions to make is to make higher level decisions about how our lives are structured, in a way that eliminates many decisions we would otherwise have to make.

2/ Ego depletion as it relates to decision making is called "decision fatigue": We make a bunch of decision, our ego reservoir drops to zero, which then leads us to make sub-optimal choices, or be paralyzed with indecision.

1/ There is this idea in psychology, coming largely from the work of R Baumeister, that when we exert self control or make decisions, it's as if we deplete a reservoir of energy that allows us to do these things. This effect is termed "ego depletion."
